article_text: Talk about having your priorities upside down in the Missouri General Assembly. Legislative leaders wrapped up the first half of their session celebrating bills that could potentially cancel welfare benefits for more than 20,000 of the state’s poorest citizens, two-thirds of them children. But lawmakers have made no progress on limiting handouts for themselves in the form of campaign contributions and lobbyist gifts.

article_metadata.news-keywords: Missouri, legislature, ethics, welfare, reform, TANF

article_metadata.title: Missouri legislators cut benefits for the poor, not for themselves | The Kansas City Star

Talk about having your priorities upside down in the Missouri General Assembly.
But lawmakers have made no progress on limiting handouts for themselves in the form of campaign contributions and lobbyist gifts.
Legislative leaders wrapped up the first half of their session celebrating bills that could potentially cancel welfare benefits for more than 20,000 of the state’s poorest citizens, two-thirds of them children.
